facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 292 and 312 of 1950 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 292 and 312 of 1950. Appeals from the Judgment and Order of the High

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order of High Court of Judicature at Hyderabad in Cases Nos. 180-181 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeals from the Judgment and Order of the High Court of Judicature at Hyderabad  Ansari, Qamar Hasan and Manohar Pershad JJ.  in Cases Nos. 180-181 of 1954

facts.text: Dewan Bahadur Ramgopal Mills Company Ltd. registered on 14th February 1920 at Hyderabad in Nizam territories.

anchor.surface_text: The Mills Company was registered on the 14th February, 1920, at Hyderabad in the then territories of His Exalted Highness the Nizam. The appellants were registered as a private limited companypany at Bombay

facts.text: Appellants registered as private limited company at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were registered as a private limited companypany at Bombay on agreement was entered into between the Mills Company. and the appellants appointing the appellants its Agents

facts.text: Agreement entered between Mills Company and appellants appointing appellants as Agents for 30 years.

anchor.surface_text: on agreement was entered into between the Mills Company. and the appellants appointing the appellants its Agents for a period of 30 years on certain terms and companyditions therein recorded.

facts.text: Appellants received remuneration from Mills Company as Agents for Fasli years 1351 and 1352.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants throughout worked only as the Agents of the Mills Company and for the Fasli years 1351 and 1352 they received their remuneration under the terms of the Agency agreement.

facts.text: Notice issued under section 13 of Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Regulation by Excess Profits Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: A numberice was issued under section 13 of the Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Regulation by the Excess Profits Tax Officer calling upon the appellants to pay the, amount of tax appertaining to these chargeable account-

facts.text: Excess Profits Tax Officer assessed appellants on 24th April 1944 at Rs. 8,957 for Fasli 1351 and Rs. 83,768 for Fasli 1352.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention of the appellants was negatived and on the 24th April, 1944, the Excess Profits Tax Officer made an order assessing the income of the appellants for the accounting periods 1351 and 1352 Fasli at Rs. 8,957 and Rs. 83,768 respectively

facts.text: Appeal by appellants to Deputy Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax disallowed.

anchor.surface_text: and assessed the tax accordingly. An appeal was taken by the appellants to the Deputy Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax who disallowed the same.

facts.text: Commissioner rejected application under section 48(2) for statement of case; High Court directed via petition under section 48(3).

anchor.surface_text: An application made by the appellants under section 48 2  for statement of the case to the High Court was rejected by the Commissioner and the appellants filed a petition to the High Court under section 48 3  to companypel the Commissioner to state the case to the High Court.

facts.text: Commissioner submitted statement of case on 26th February 1946.

anchor.surface_text: An order was made by the High,Court on this petition directing the Commissioner to state the case and the statement of the case was submitted by the Commis- sioner on the 26th February, 1946.

facts.text: Four specific questions referred by Commissioner to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Four questions were referred by the Commissioner to the High Courts as under- Whether the Petitioner Company is a partnership firm or a registered firm ? Whether under the terms of the agreement the petitioner is an employee of the Mills Company or is carrying on business ?

facts.text: Full Bench of High Court decided questions 2 and 3 against appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The Full Bench of the High Court delivered their judgment the majority deciding the questions  2  and  3  which were the only questions companysidered determinative of the reference against the appellants.

facts.text: Appeals to Judicial Committee; after merger of Hyderabad, transferred to Supreme Court on 12th December 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants appealed to the Judicial Committee. But before the Judicial Committee heard the appeals there was a merger of the territories of Hyderabad with India. The appeals finally came for hearing before the Supreme Court Bench at Hyderabad on the 12th December, 1950,

facts.text: Appellants contended remuneration not income, profits or gains from business, outside Excess Profits Tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants submitted their accounts and companytended that the remuneration received by them from the Mills Company was number taxable on the ground that it is was number income, profits or gains from business and was outside the pale of the Excess Profits Tax Regulation.

facts.text: Supreme Court held appellants are agents of Mills Company, not servants.

anchor.surface_text: Considering the position of the appellants in the light of the above principles it is numberdoubt true that the appellants were to act as the agents of the Company and carry on the general management of the business of the Company subject to the companytrol and supervision of the Directors.

facts.text: Remuneration of appellants is commission of 2-1/2 per cent on sale proceeds of yarn, cloth etc.

anchor.surface_text: The remuneration of the appellants as such Agents was to be a companymission of per cent on the amount of sale proceeds of all yarn cloth and other produce of the Company  including companyton grown  which companymission was to be exclusive of any remuneration or wages payable

facts.text: Appellants' objects include acting as agents and carrying on all kinds of agency business.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were registered as a private limited companypany having their registered office in Bombay and the objects for which they were incorporated were the following To act as agents for Governments or Authorities or for any bankers, manufacturers, merchants, shippers, Joint Stock Companies and others and carry on all kinds of agency business.

facts.text: Agency agreement allows appellants to sub-delegate powers (Article 118).

anchor.surface_text: Article 1 18 authorised the agents to sub-delegate all or any of the powers, authorities and discretions for the time being vested in them, and in particular from time to time to provide by the appointment of an attorney or attorneys,

facts.text: Supreme Court held activities of appellants constitute carrying on business.

anchor.surface_text: All these factors taken, into companysideration alongwith the fixity of tenure, the nature of remuneration and the assignability of their rights, are sufficient to enable us to companye to the companyclusion that the activities of the appellants as the agents of the Company companystituted a business

facts.text: Remuneration received by appellants is income, profits or gains from business, liable for excess profits tax.

anchor.surface_text: the remuneration which the appellants received from the Company under the terms of the Agency Agreement was income, profits or gain from business.

facts.text: Agency agreement for 30 years from registration, continuable until resignation.

anchor.surface_text: The Agency agreement which was executed in pursuance of the appointment under Article 115, provided that the appellants and their assigns were to be the Agents of the Company for a period of 30 years from the date of registration of the Company and they were to companytinue to act

facts.text: Clauses 3 and 4 of agency agreement grant broad management powers to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Clauses 3 and 4 of the agency agreement are important and may be set out in extenso - Subject to the companytrol and supervision of the Directors, the said Lachminaravan Ramgopal and Son Limited shall have the general companyduct and management of the business and affairs of the companypany

facts.text: Appellants can appoint sub-agents in Bombay and other places.

anchor.surface_text: and the appelants were entitled to appoint any person or persons in Bombay to act as their Agents in Bombay and any other places in companynection with the business if the Company.

facts.text: Merger of Hyderabad territories with India occurred before Judicial Committee hearing.

anchor.surface_text: But before the Judicial Committee heard the appeals there was a merger of the territories of Hyderabad with India.

holdings.text: the principle of exclusion of the income from the category of business income by reason of its depending wholly or mainly on the personal qualifications of the assessee would not apply because the income could not be said to be income from profession and neither a partnership firm nor a registered company as such could be said to be possessed of any personal qualifications in the matter of the acquisition of that income.

anchor.surface_text: The questions 1 and 4 which were referred by the Commissioner to the High Court at Hyderabad have not been seriously pressed before us. Whether the appellants are a partnership firm or a registered company the principle of exclusion of the income from the category of business income by reason of its depending wholly or mainly on the personal qualifications of the assessee would not apply because the income could not be said to be income from profession and neither a partnership firm nor a registered company as such could be said to be possessed of any personal qualifications in the matter of the acquisition of that income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exclusion for personal qualifications applies only to individuals; firms and companies lack personal qualifications.

holdings.text: the appellants were the agents of the Company and not merely the servants of the Company remunerated by wages or salary.

anchor.surface_text: All these circumstances together with the power of sub- delegation reserved under Article 118 in our opinion go to establish that the appellants were the agents of the Company and not merely the servants of the Company remunerated by wages or salary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied servant-agent distinction from authorities: general supervision not direct control over manner of work; commission remuneration, sub-delegation, assignability, fixed tenure indicate agency.

holdings.text: the activities of the appellants as the agents of the Company constituted a business

anchor.surface_text: All these factors taken, into consideration alongwith the fixity of tenure, the nature of remuneration and the assignability of their rights, are sufficient to enable us to come to the conclusion that the activities of the appellants as the agents of the Company constituted a business

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factors including continuity of operations, company objects for agency business, broad management powers, nature of activities as services, even if restricted to one concern; analogy to Esplen case for companies.

holdings.text: the remuneration which the appellants received from the Company under the terms of the Agency Agreement was income, profits or gain from business.

anchor.surface_text: the remuneration which the appellants received from the Company under the terms of the Agency Agreement was income, profits or gain from business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from holding that agency activities constitute business; remuneration is commission from such business.

holdings.text: The activities of the appellants certainly did come within the inclusive definition of business which is given in section 2 clause 4 of the Excess Profits Tax Regulation, Hyderabad.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Agency management falls within inclusive definition of business (trade, commerce, etc., or services); personal qualification exclusion inapplicable to companies.

precedents.citation: William Esplen, Son and Swainston, Limited v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue 1

anchor.surface_text: Reference may be made in this companytext to William Esplen, Son and Swainston, Limited v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue  1 . In that case a private limited companypany was incorporated for carrying on business as naval architects and companysulting engineers. Before the formation of the companypany, a partnership had existed for many year between three persons who, on incorporation, became the sole shareholders and directors of the companypany.

precedents.case_name: William Esplen Son and Swainston Ltd v Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: A limited company cannot carry on a profession dependent mainly on personal qualifications of individuals but carries on trade or business
precedents.cited_holding: the company was not carrying on the profession of naval architects because profits of profession depend on personal qualifications which a company lacks; it was carrying on trade or business

precedents.cited_proposition: The purpose for which a limited company comes into existence is relevant to determining if its activities constitute carrying on business
precedents.cited_holding: a limited company comes into existence for some particular purpose, and that purpose is to be considered in deciding if its activities amount to carrying on business

precedents.cited_proposition: When determining if activities constitute carrying on business, it is material whether a company is doing it

anchor.surface_text: The questions 1 and 4 which were referred by the Commissioner to the High Court at Hyderabad have not been seriously pressed before us. Whether the appellants are a partnership firm or a registered company the principle of exclusion of the income from the category of business income by reason of its depending wholly or mainly on the personal qualifications of the assessee would not apply because the income could not be said to be income from profession and neither a partnership firm nor a registered company as such could be said to be possessed of any personal qualifications in the matter of the acquisition of that income.
